steps.title: Wet your paper.
steps.content: Wet your paper. Get a rag wet and splotch water all over the paper you plan to dye. Allow excess water to drop off into a sink.

steps.title: Mix watercolors or food coloring in various squirt or spray bottles.
steps.content: Mix watercolors or food coloring in various squirt or spray bottles . Use squirt bottles [1] X Research source to create blotches of color and spray bottles [2] X Research source to create larger spatters of color. Make sure you mix the appropriate amount of water with your dyes according to their directions.

steps.title: Place your paper onto a surface you don't mind getting colored.
steps.content: Place your paper onto a surface you don't mind getting colored. You might cover a table or countertop with several layers of newspaper or place your paper in a large, shallow tin. You can even complete the activity on the ground outside, weather permitting. It's also a good idea to protect your clothes by wearing a smock , apron or old t-shirt.

steps.title: Squirt or spray the dye on the paper.
steps.content: Squirt or spray the dye on the paper. There's no right or wrong way to apply the color, just use your imagination. Use various colors for a true tie-dyed look. If you want to create symmetrical patterns, fold the paper in half before applying the color.

steps.title: Hold the paper over a pan, sink or outdoors to allow the colors to run.
steps.content: Hold the paper over a pan, sink or outdoors to allow the colors to run. The liquid dye will run and bleed across the wet paper. You can twist the paper as it drips to create further designs.

steps.title: Allow the paper to dry.
steps.content: Allow the paper to dry. If you chose to fold the paper, unfold it, then lay the paper down flat on a towel. Let the paper air dry for at least 30 minutes. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Add coffee grounds into a pan.
steps.content: Add coffee grounds into a pan. Choose a pan large enough to also hold the paper you plan to dye. Don't worry if you aren't sure how many grounds to add, you can always add more to strengthen the coffee as it steeps. [4] X Research source The more coffee you add, the darker your paper will be. If you add much coffee, some tiny particles of it can stay on the paper, and if you draw or write on it, the pen can pick them up and get blocked. But it will still work for wrapping gifts or even for printing.

steps.title: Pour boiling water into the pan.
steps.content: Pour boiling water into the pan. Allow the water and coffee grounds to steep at least five minutes. If the resulting liquid isn't dark enough, add more grounds and allow it to steep a few minutes more.

steps.title: Add a piece of paper to the pan, and let it steep.
steps.content: Add a piece of paper to the pan, and let it steep. How long you allow the paper to steep is completely up to you, depending on how dark you want the paper to be stained. Various projects could require paper to steep anywhere from five minutes to overnight. If you would like to create symmetrical stained designs, fold the paper into squares, triangles or strips before placing it in the liquid.

steps.title: Remove the paper from the coffee.
steps.content: Remove the paper from the coffee. Wait until the paper is just a shade or two lighter than what you desire, then remove it from the coffee. The paper will darken a shade or two more as it dries.

steps.title: Hang the paper to dry.
steps.content: Hang the paper to dry. You can clip it to a clothesline or a curtain rod. Be careful as you handle the paper, since it will be more fragile while it's wet. Drying time can vary based on the type of paper and where it's hanging. You can test it with your hand to know when its fully dried. If you're not satisfied with the shade once the paper dries, simply repeat steps 3-5.

steps.title: Color the paper with markers.
steps.content: Color the paper with markers. [5] X Research source Get multiple colors of markers and scribble all over the paper in whatever designs you like. The more solid blocks of color, the better the end result. To create a symmetrical design, fold soft absorbent papers into halves, fourths or eighths. Hold a marker down on the top layer until the ink has soaked through all of the layers. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Wet the paper.
steps.content: Wet the paper. You can get the paper wet by spraying it with or dipping it into water. When the marker gets wet, it will bleed and blur, resembling tie dye. You want the paper to be wet but not dripping.

steps.title: Let the paper dry.
steps.content: Let the paper dry. If you've folded the paper, unfold it and lay it flat on a dry surface. Once it's dry, you can use it for wrapping paper, as the background of a special note or even the basis of paper flowers.
